title: 110_hr4178
content: The Act titled "Emergency Mortgage Loan Modification Act of 2007" provides a safe harbor for holders involved in troubled debt restructuring for residential mortgage loans. The Emergency Mortgage Loan Modification Act of 2007 introduces a safe harbor for holders engaged in troubled debt restructuring with regard to residential mortgage loans. This new section provides protection for creditors, assignees, servicers, securitizers, or other holders of residential mortgage loans who enter into qualified loan modifications or workout plans after January 1, 2004. The Emergency Mortgage Loan Modification Act of 2007 establishes criteria for a qualified loan modification or workout plan for troubled debt restructuring of residential mortgage loans. It also defines a qualified mortgage as any residential mortgage loan meeting specific conditions. A qualified mortgage is a residential mortgage loan with a first lien on the property and an annual percentage rate below certain thresholds. The qualified mortgage must have an annual percentage rate below certain thresholds and be a first lien on the property. The qualified mortgage must have an annual percentage rate below certain thresholds and be a first lien on the property. It should not exceed the most recent conventional mortgage rate by more than 375 basis points. The contract interest rate on commitments for fixed-rate first mortgages is based on the Federal Reserve Statistical Release on selected interest rates. A residential mortgage loan is defined as a loan secured by a lien on an owner-occupied dwelling that is not a qualified mortgage. A securitization vehicle refers to an entity created by the issuer for issuing securities. The term 'securitizer' refers to the person transferring residential mortgage loans to a securitization vehicle. This section applies to qualified loan modification plans initiated within a specific period. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include provisions for qualified loan modification plans initiated within a specific 6-month period. Safe harbor provision for holders involved in troubled debt restructuring for residential mortgage loans.
